Catch-All Clause
At last Friday's Board meeting
the final "catch-all" clause was
added to the regulations, making
necessary a two-thirds vote to
amend or waive them. The final
clau.se met with some opposition
from representatives who felt
that "adding this (clause) does
not change the present situation." However the majority
sentiment was that the twothirds stipulation "is a reversal
of the previous trend (of ganging up to bar a fraternity's admittance) because it would take
more votes to keep a fraternity
out."

Previous to the examination
period in January the Board
passed the most important innovation in its new program, a
clause providing for automatic
acceptance into regular IFB
membership after a provisional
period.
The clause states: "Any provisional (IFB) member shall become permanent after three rush
seasons, provided that it has:
1) The ownership or option on a
house; 2) A total of at least 21
pledges taken in three years, not
less than five of these being taken
in any one year; 3) Sound
finances; 4) Not flagrantly
violated IFB jurisdiction.
Goes For Others, Too
An additional clause states
that any new fraternity's ties
with the university will be
severed "if it does not meet with
the above qualifications within
five years from the date of its

IFB vice-pregident Pete Doyle
expressed the feeling that "if any
fraternity meets the objection of
two-thirds of the fraternities,
that's a pretty good indication
that it's not wanted or needed."
No Stalling
Tie crux of the newly-passed
regulations is that any fraternity
admitted as a provisional IFB
member can automatically guide
itself into permanent membership without the stalling votes of
the Board. Thus the Board has
removed the responsibility for
admittance of new members from
the shoulders of its own representatives and placed most of it
on the applying fraternity itself.
The only block the IFB can
impose must come through its
own system of violations, a reversal of the policy in practice
up to the recent ZBT squabble.
Sections of the regulations
passed earlier concerned the
criteria necessary for being recognized as a legitimate social
fraternity and those by which
such a group would show itself
worthy of provisional IFB membership.

Student Activities Commission
Chairman Dick Einaugler announced this week that the
Glenn Miller Orchestra will bring
their attractive vocalist Lorry
Peters with them on their trip
to Baltimore next month.
Miss Peters and the Miller ensemble will appear at the university prom, to be held on

on sale at $2 each while graduates, medical students, nurses,
employees and alumni are paying $4 per couple.

Songstress Peters has been
singing with the band for some
time after previous engagements
with other big-name groups A
native of Connecticut, she graduated from Syracuse University
in 1954 where she was a radio
major.
Having wanted to sing professionally "for as long as I can
remember," Miss Peters appeared
on several Kiddie Revues at an
early age. Working as a secretary
at the NBC studios in New York
after her college graduation, she
kept up her musical studies and
worked at bit-singing in radio
and TV commercials until band
leader Ray McKinley heard and
signed her for a regular job as
vocalist. Since then she has
travelled throughout the country
with the Miller band.

Gambling
Boldly asserting that they could no longer afford to
"pass the buck" and that "positive action" was imminently
necessary the Dormitory Students Representative Council
enacted a resolution this week barring gambling in the
Snack Bar.
To say that the News-Letter was surprised by this
action would be a gross understatement. It seems an
almost complete reversal of an earlier stand, for, when
the gambling controversy broke into the open shortly
before semester exams, the DSRC seemed firmly resolved
to the hope that the problem would work itself out with
the help of semester grades, publicity and the meeting
the Deans were to have with the gamblers. The first two
had little or no effect on the gamblers. The last strangely
had not occurred before the DSRC met Monday.
The only indication of the resultant legislation came
with formation of a committee composed of the various
divergent factions on the Council. But formation of committees is a popular device of student organizations. And
conception is usually the extent of their achievement.
This committee, however, returned to the Council
with an unexpected recommendation—a ban on gambling
throughout the dormitories. This was quite a good deal
more than President Leo Tonkin's demand last month
for a mere statement of policy. It is more than the Council finally ratified.
Why this shift? None of the committee members
spelled out their reasons in the same way. They ranged
from a desire to achieve a "general norm of dorm behavior" to a feeling that passing the buck would not be
tolerated by the administration, which might then reclaim some of the DSRCs autonomy.
Whatever the stated reasons, the action certainly
wasn't hasty. It seems a conscientious desire on the part of
the dorm representatives to enhance the general welfare of
the community by relieving a public gathering place (the
snack bar) of the ogre of gambling. There can be no
doubt that a representative group can legislate for such
purposes. But it is impossible to legislate customs. And
in the final analysis the extent of the protection offered
by the resolution and the extent to which gambling will
be curtailed will depend on the wishes of individual
dorm inhabitants. If they want to gamble, they will find
a way to do it—either evading the snack bar restrictions
by playing for "togetherness and then paying off togetherness," or by moving games to lounges or rooms, where,
unlike the snack bar, noise will become a disturbing factor.
This resolution's success depends on the scope and
effect of its enforcement. It fails if it obliterates all cardplaying, for suspicion is rarely far from conviction, as
was seen earlier in this gambling case, when the gamblers
were placed under an onus of suspicion of destruction
and theft simply on grounds that they had the motive to
commit these violations.
If this resolution merely drives the gambling to
places where it can have a greater disturbing effect on
the dormitories, it also fails. ,

Upon her fragrant young skull and went away, meaning with
all his heart to be faithful.

Gambling
Boldly asserting that they could no longer afford to
"pass the buck" and that "positive action" was imminently
necessary the Dormitory Students Representative Council
enacted a resolution this week barring gambling in the
Snack Bar.
To say that the News-Letter was surprised by this
action would be a gross understatement. It seems an
almost complete reversal of an earlier stand, for, when
the gambling controversy broke into the open shortly
before semester exams, the DSRC seemed firmly resolved
to the hope that the problem would work itself out with
the help of semester grades, publicity and the meeting
the Deans were to have with the gamblers. The first two
had little or no effect on the gamblers. The last strangely
had not occurred before the DSRC met Monday.
The only indication of the resultant legislation came
with formation of a committee composed of the various
divergent factions on the Council. But formation of committees is a popular device of student organizations. And
conception is usually the extent of their achievement.
This committee, however, returned to the Council
with an unexpected recommendation—a ban on gambling
throughout the dormitories. This was quite a good deal
more than President Leo Tonkin's demand last month
for a mere statement of policy. It is more than the Council finally ratified.
Why this shift? None of the committee members
spelled out their reasons in the same way. They ranged
from a desire to achieve a "general norm of dorm behavior" to a feeling that passing the buck would not be
tolerated by the administration, which might then reclaim some of the DSRCs autonomy.
Whatever the stated reasons, the action certainly
wasn't hasty. It seems a conscientious desire on the part of
the dorm representatives to enhance the general welfare of
the community by relieving a public gathering place (the
snack bar) of the ogre of gambling. There can be no
doubt that a representative group can legislate for such
purposes. But it is impossible to legislate customs. And
in the final analysis the extent of the protection offered
by the resolution and the extent to which gambling will
be curtailed will depend on the wishes of individual
dorm inhabitants. If they want to gamble, they will find
a way to do it—either evading the snack bar restrictions
by playing for "togetherness and then paying off togetherness," or by moving games to lounges or rooms, where,
unlike the snack bar, noise will become a disturbing factor.
This resolution's success depends on the scope and
effect of its enforcement. It fails if it obliterates all cardplaying, for suspicion is rarely far from conviction, as
was seen earlier in this gambling case, when the gamblers
were placed under an onus of suspicion of destruction
and theft simply on grounds that they had the motive to
commit these violations.
If this resolution merely drives the gambling to
places where it can have a greater disturbing effect on
the dormitories, it also fails. ,
